ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How the Age of Enlightenment influenced art.
visual analysis, art theory, enlightenment history and philosophy
I learned so much about Enlightenment Visual Art. I can't believe it all fits in my brain to be honest. Beyond actual content, I think I have grown in my visual analysis abilities.

This course provides such a unique lens to look at visual arts during that special time period. I didnt know anything about visual arts in the Age of Reason at all before I took this course. I have learned so much by the end of it, not just about art history, but also concerning larger topics such as the relationship between nature and art, truth and beauty, art and morality, the subjective experience of the beholder, the aesthetic of fragments and ruins, etc. This course has changed the way I look at the world.
Writing and analytical skills! I am much better at thinking about connections between history and contemporary philosophy now.

I gained a breadth of understanding and new perspective of the Enlightenment period.  I practiced looking and seeing, and interpreting through an artistic lens the academic/intellectual progress of the period.  The way art and artists influence society and knowledge dissemination is wonderful, and by studying this period I encountered beautiful examples of the cross disciplinary achievements.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think if we slowed down and discussed some of the kew works collaboratively it would improve my understanding of the work.
The content is very interesting but too much is covered in each lecture. The professor should pair it down a bit.

Strength of the course if the teaching staff. Professor Suthor is a very engaging lecturer and her explanation of artwork makes you look and think about art in an entirely different lens. Teaching assistants were also very good at leading discussion sections. 

Weakness is that the material at the beginning of the semester was challenging and hard to understand without prior experience/knowledge in philosophy.

This course is so comprehensive which I think is both its greatest strength and greatest weakness. So awesome because I feel like I learned SO much but also tough because I often felt really lost but overall I do think being so full of information weighs as more of a pro than con because I will be taking away what I resonated with most and had choices of what to engage with because there was SO much material.

One of my favorite parts of the course is its interdisciplinary nature. I always knew art history is quite interdisciplinary, but I never truly experienced it by myself until I took this course. It amazingly brings together philosophy, science, and art. Our reading range from scientific treatises such as Newtons Optics and Goethes Theory of Colors to the intellectual project of Diderot and DAlemberts Encyclopedia and to aesthetic theories such as Winckelmanns Description of the Torso of the Belvedere and Lessings Laocoon. We also learn about Descartes and Kants understandings of the Enlightenment and Rousseaus influence on sentimentalism in visual art. Another highlight of this course is our frequent visits to the YUAG and the Beinecke Library. Imagine reading a 17th or 18th century primary source at the weekend, and then actually get to examine a copy of it closely during that weeks section. This courses engagement with collections in the YUAG and the Beinecke makes it so much fun.
One possible weakness of the course is that since it is organized thematically rather than chronologically, sometimes the jumping back and forth along the timeline could get a bit confusing, but this issue can get resolved during the review process. This weakness might also turn out to be a strength, since it allows us to compare artists working in the same medium or genre with one another, and so to understand the full range of artistic positions in this complex period in European art history.

This class has a very large breadth and covered many different ideas in detail, but sometimes it was difficult to see how each "module" per se contributed to the larger overall landscape of enlightenment ideas.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they have already taken several art history courses and were really interested in the subject material!
Yes! Professor Suthor was one of the best professors I have had at Yale and her classes made me enjoy and have a greater appreciation for art history.

I definitely think this is a niche course. If a student is interested in art history and strengthening their visual analysis skills then for sure. But if you're someone who is not interested in either of those things, this would be a hard class to take and I wouldn't recommend because of how dense and technical it is.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in art history or the Age of Reason. The workload of this course is quite manageable while you can really learn a lot if you do the readings carefully, attend the lectures, and engage in discussion in sections. It took me roughly 3 hours every week outside class to do the reading. Approaching midterm and final exams, Prof. Suthor also held recap sections and provided sample questions and led sections to help us get prepared for the exams. The final paper is also a lot of fun since you get to choose your own topic, including artworks you can observe in person in the YUAG, and let your own voice emerge from your writing.
Great course if you are interested in art, philosophy, or the enlightenment.
Absolutely.  Professor Suthor and the TA's are amazing, the lectures are engaging and the artworks are stunning.

extras.title: HSAR 281 01 - Visual Arts in Age of Reason
